My name is Jim Pen and this is joint work with my advisor Tokyo Kennedy Anne May 10 so.
I propose a heterogeneous conditional random field to perform joint detection and segmentation of cell regions in microscopic images.
So as we can see in the left figure, separate detection and segmentation has this kind of fraud.
That is, segmentation is performed after detection is done.
As a result, any mistakes made in the detection stage do not have any chance to be corrected by.
In contrast, joined in joint detection segmentation.
As shown in the right figure, no early decision is made, so detection and segmentation can mutually enhance each other.
However, to perform joint detection segmentation, a conventional CRF is not applicable because this model is not identifiable in this setting.
And to overcome this problem, we propose a heterogeneous conditional random field by carefully designing the state sets and special inference rules.

So here a major difference is that in heterogeneous CRF, different nodes have different state sets, so this is where the name heterogeneous comes from and it can be proved that our model has full representational power while remaining identifiable.
An experimental results have shown that our model outperforms both the conventional CRF Anna separate detection segmentation.
So to learn more about our model, please come to our poster.
Thank you.
So good morning, my name is Matthias Schneider.
I'm going to introduce our brick and mortar base, respiratory motion compensation for cardiac interventions.
This work has been done at University of Erlangen, Nuremberg together with Professor Hanukkah and my advisor Hari Sundar from Siemens Corporate Research and Shenyang Su.

So as you all know, minimally invasive cardiac interventions are commonly performed on the X Ray guidance, but for extremely hard cases such as chronic total occlusions, it's very difficult for the for the cardiologist to perform these these procedures purely based on the life of roske P. That's why would like to incorporate preoperative information into the imaging workflow.
This is done as this year in the middle by 23 registration of a preoperative CT data set with the X Ray.
Data obtained during the intervention.
However, these X Rays sequences are heavily affected by both cardiac and respiratory motion.

That's why the registration has to be dynamically re computed during the entire intervention, which is extremely difficult because there is only very little structural information contained in the X Ray images.
So what we propose in our work is to train a statistical motion model to learn the patient specific breathing pattern and to leverage this model.
To robustly do this registration during the intervention.
So if you want to know more about our proposed motion model, please stop by our poster and I'm happy to meet you there, thanks.
